entry.title: Fushimi Inari Taisha・伏見稲荷大社

link.title: Fushimi Inari Taisha・伏見稲荷大社

entry.content:
With Kyoto reopening from a successful mitigation of the COVID-19 pandemic, I thought it would be auspicious to visit the famous Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine before it gets crowded again.

Beautiful morning sunlight illuminates a hundred vermillion gates (torii), each one purchased in gratitude to the gods for success in one of numerous endeavors.

My idea was to shoot with a really wide lens for a different look, but ultimately I ended up cropping back down to the essential elements of this classic view.

entry.title: Shoden-ji・正伝時
entry.content:
View of the rock garden at Shoden-ji Temple, in the very northern part of Kyoto.

Notice that the foliage behind the garden has been designed to frame Mt. Hiei in the distance. This is an example of “borrowed scenery” used in Japanese gardens.

It is said that David Bowie used to frequent this temple.

entry.title: Shaved Ice・かき氷
entry.content:
A sign for Shaved Ice, Kakigori; a sign of summer.

Kakigori is a dessert, a giant mound of shaved ice, generally flavored with syrup or fruit; but tea, coffee, nuts, chocolate... the sky is the limit.

In the hands of the best chefs, it’s more like eating freshly fallen snow; fluffy, not crunchy; refreshing!
entry.summary: A sign for Shaved Ice, Kakigori; a sign of summer.
